source.2dfc0e0e:
# for cleaning and extracting the questions
def get_ques_and_clean_df(df):
    cols = df.columns
    names = df.iloc[0,:]
    questions = {a : b  for a, b in zip(cols , names)}
    df.drop([0] , inplace = True)
    df.reset_index(inplace=True)
    df.drop(labels='index',axis=1, inplace=True)
    return questions

# for printing the questions
def print_questions(questions):
    print(f'total number of questions  = {len(questions)}')
    for i in questions.keys():
        print(f'{i} : {questions[i]} \n')

source.2441e0f5:
# function to get the top5 df
def _get_top5_df(df , label):
    df[label] = df[label].replace('United States of America' , 'USA')
    df[label] = df[label].replace('United States' , 'USA')
    df[label] = df[label].replace("People 's Republic of China" , 'China')
    df[label] = df[label].replace('United Kingdom' , 'UK')
    top_countries_value = df[label].value_counts()
    others = top_countries_value.iloc[7:].sum()
    top_countries_value = top_countries_value.iloc[0:6]
    top_countries_value.append(pd.Series(data=[others] , index=['others']))
    top_countries_percent = top_countries_value.copy()
    for  i in top_countries_percent:
        top_countries_percent =  top_countries_percent.replace(i , (i/ top_countries_value.sum()) * 100)
    return top_countries_value , top_countries_percent

source.b853dbda:
#function to extract yearwise features for male and female
def obtain_yearswise_features(label1 : list , label2: list):
    years = [2017 , 2018 , 2019 , 2020]
    _2017 = India_2017.loc[India_2017[label1[0]] == 'Male' , label2[0]].value_counts()
    _2018 = India_2018.loc[India_2018[label1[1]] == 'Male' ,label2[1]].value_counts()
    _2019 = India_2019.loc[India_2019[label1[2]] == 'Male' ,label2[2]].value_counts()
    _2020 = India_2020.loc[India_2020[label1[3]] == 'Male' ,label2[3]].value_counts()

    yearwise_male = pd.concat([_2017 , _2018 , _2019 , _2020] , axis=1)
    yearwise_male.columns = years
    
    _2017 = India_2017.loc[India_2017[label1[0]] == 'Female' , label2[0]].value_counts()
    _2018 = India_2018.loc[India_2018[label1[1]] == 'Female' ,label2[1]].value_counts()
    _2019 = India_2019.loc[India_2019[label1[2]] == 'Female' ,label2[2]].value_counts()
    _2020 = India_2020.loc[India_2020[label1[3]] == 'Female' ,label2[3]].value_counts()

    yearwise_female = pd.concat([_2017 , _2018 , _2019 , _2020] , axis=1)
    yearwise_female.columns = years
    return yearwise_male , yearwise_female

source.8f3631a4:
# to genrate the bin labels and bins in proper sorted order
def generate_bins(df , label):
    # preparing bins and labels for binning
    sal_bins = df[label].unique()
    labels_sal = sal_bins.copy()
    labels_sal = list(labels_sal)
    labels_sal.pop(labels_sal.index(np.nan))
    sal_bins = [a.split('-')[0] for a in sal_bins if type(a) == str ]
    sal_bins = [int(decoma(x)) for x in sal_bins]
    sal_bins.sort()
    sal_bins.append(np.NaN)
    # list comprehension to sort the string intervals in correct order using age_bins list
    bin_labels_sal = [c for a in sal_bins for c in labels_sal if int(decoma(c.split('-')[0])) == a]
    return sal_bins , bin_labels_sal
source.55663d10:
def plot_sal(df , label1 ,label2 , fig , row  , showlegend=False):
    #extracting data for common 
    sal_df = df[[label1 , label2]]
    #genrating bin labels
    _ , labels = generate_bins(sal_df, label2)
    #getting total salary distribtuion
    df_main = pd.DataFrame(sal_df[label2].value_counts())
    df_main = df_main.reindex(labels)
    # drawing the first graph row =x , col = 2*x - 1
    fig.add_trace(go.Funnel(x=df_main.index , y=df_main[label2] , orientation='v',width=0.8, text=df_main[label2], showlegend=False), row=row , col=1)
    fig.update_traces(texttemplate='%{text:.2s}', textposition='outside' , textfont= dict(size=14 , family='Aerial, sans-serif'), textangle=0, row = row , col=1)
    #plotting gender wise
    color = {'Male':'green' , 'Female':'yellow'}
    for g in sal_df[label1].unique():
        df_sub = sal_df.loc[sal_df[label1] == g]
        df_sub = pd.DataFrame(df_sub[label2].value_counts())
        df_sub = df_sub.reindex(labels)
        fig.add_trace(go.Bar(y=df_sub.index , x = df_sub[label2] , orientation='h' ,name=g, marker=dict(color=color[g]) , showlegend=showlegend), row=row , col=2)

source.b5b0c919:
def clean_df2(df):
    df.fillna(0 , inplace=True)
    years = [2018 , 2020]
    df.loc['Jupyter(JupyterLab,JupyterNotebooks,etc)' , 2018] = df.loc['Jupyter/IPython' , 2018] 
    
    df.drop(['Jupyter/IPython'], axis='index', inplace=True)
    for year in years:
        df.loc['VisualStudio/VisualStudioCode' , year] = df.loc['VisualStudio' , year] + df.loc['VisualStudioCode' , year] + df.loc['VisualStudioCode(VSCode)' , year]
    df.drop(['VisualStudioCode(VSCode)' , 'VisualStudio' , 'VisualStudioCode'] , axis='index' ,inplace=True)
    df.drop(['Other'] , inplace=True)

source.dbe7d009: ## CONCLUSION --- 1. The participation from has increased and showing a increasin trend in the Data science 2. There is now evidence that suggest that there are discrimnative practices being carried out in the data science domain on the basis of gender (based on the salary distribution , formal education) which is one fo the purpose of starting with gender demographics, to prove that Data science is breaking breaking sterotype 3. there are some key points that we can consider for our further study - when it comes to formal education Bachelors have the highes concentration - Data scientist and Software engineer are two most popular job titles - Most data scientist have a pay under USD 10,000 p.a. we can look at the salary distribtuion accorss work experience to understand it better - C/C++ is the second most popular language, we can look at popular language accross job titles to understand why so this is it for this part we will be exploring some fun insight in the second part STAY TUNED !!

source.e4ccd2ad:
from the above figure we can see that among all the top5 countires **India** is the only one which shows growth for all the consecutive years. while the countires like **USA** show a huge decline in the number of participants. There could be multiple reason for this decline. following might be some of them - Kaggle might be losing its popularity in America on the other hand it is continously gaining it in India - the Data science community in USA are less active and interested with the survey compared to their Indian counterparts - in USA Data Science has now become a well established domain but in India its still emerging so data scientist and companies are more inclined to these surveys to understand the ongoing trends in it. - not all working data scientists in USA are involved in competetive Data science all these arguements are based on intution so I would suggest not to directly jump on these but read further as we will unfold more insights as we go deeper into the data
In the following you can see the growth in number of participants years by year in India
source.bab44866: Again the distribution is very similar accorss both the genders. so far our analysis shows that all trends are similar in both sections Males and females. so i think it is enough to conclude are study on gender demographics in Indian Data science community

source.37363277:
now in this figure we can see that the growth between 2018 and 19 is steady in numbers but considerable in the percentage share. This is because when we look back in figure 1 in 2019 all the other countires in top 5 show decline except for India. In 2019 there was a global decline in the number of participants and that was the time India took up reached the top.
So this is one of my main reasons to study this country not because I live there but because it shows a growing trend in the popularity for ML and DS and as we will look further and have seen basic EDA notebooks most of these participants from India are students thus are Budding data scientists. This shows that students are reaaly interested in this field specially the Undergrads or Bachelors. Which is really great as this means we can expect that India is going to have a well established market for ML and DS. Right now we will be studying the Demography of Indian Data Science population and in each part we will look at a different subsection of this population Getting the Indian Datasets

source.18680f31:
so we can assume that most common salary for a person working in Data sciece domain will be under 10,000 USD p.a. but howeever in the later years (2019 , 2020) we can see that number of people working on higher compensation has increased and presumabely this trend will continue in future years, thus Data science is getting hot year by year.
looking at the gender base distribtuion of these compensation we can see that both for male and female the distribution is very identical which is a good sign as it depicts no gender based discrimnation when it comes to earning
